Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Ecological mechanisms of multilevel selection in Silene vulgaris
Award.AbstractNarration:
Some of the most important interactions in plant populations are mediated by the actions of other species, such as pollinators. This project seeks to understand how population level properties influence these cross-species interactions, thereby driving differences in plant reproductive success. Work will be conducted in wild and experimental populations of the flowering plant Silene vulgaris. Natural populations of this species maintain incredibly variable sex ratios, from 7 to 70% female. The large variability of sex ratio among populations provides an excellent natural experiment to test the hypothesis that differences in sex ratio among populations create differences in the recruitment and behavior of pollinators. Pollinator movement and behavior will be recorded, and compared with measurements of reproductive output assessed with molecular markers to determine whether and how social context affects an organism's fitness.

Understanding how population level properties drive ecological interactions is fundamental to understanding the evolutionary process. Determining how social and ecological context influence pollination biology has the potential to inform agricultural practices, which increasingly rely on natural pollinator assemblages with the recent and continued decline in domestic bees. This grant will provide support for the training of a PhD student and support research opportunities for undergraduate students at the Mountain Lake Biological Station.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although many past studies of social and sexual interactions have focused on animals, plant species are excellent model organisms to understand the effects of these interactions on phenotypic evolution. Because plants cannot move, individuals can be identified and revisited with ease over the course of an experiment. Additionally, the most important interactions in plant populations are often mediated by the actions of pollinators, and these actions can be readily observed and controlled. Finally, after fertilization, fruits develop on the maternal plant so the identification of genetic mothers is clear, the offspring are easy to collect, and seeds remain viable for decades.

The goal of this project was to understand how the sex ratio of populations affected an individual’s reproductive success in the flowering plant Silene vulgaris. For sexually reproducing plants, the sex ratio of a population describes the pool of available mates, and so is likely to impact the fitness consequences of sexual interactions. We used experimental populations that varied in sex ratio to determine whether and how sex ratio affected the fitness of individuals.  We found that the sex ratio of a population affected the recruitment and behavior of pollinators including bees and flies that were active during the day, but not pollinators such as moths that were active at night. We then used bags to control access to flowers during the day and at night, and found that only the nighttime insects were effective pollinators. Finally, we counted the number of fruits and used genetic paternity assignment in our experimental populations to quantify differences in fitness among individuals. We found that both sexes obtained highest fitness when they were relatively rare. In addition, we found that the relationship between flower size and reproductive success varied with sex ratio. Plants with larger flowers had higher fitness in populations with a high ratio of females, while plants with smaller flowers had higher fitness when females were less common. Taken together, these results suggest that inefficient pollinators can alter the form of selection acting on floral phenotypes. This surprising conclusion highlights the importance of understanding the social and ecological context in which phenotypic selection occurs.

This project supported the dissertation of the co-PI, who successfully defended his dissertation in July 2016, and began post-doctoral research at Texas Tech University in August 2016. The project also provided research training for two undergraduate students through the National Science Foundation Research Experiences for Undergraduates at the Mountain Lake Biological Station. Both undergraduates designed and investigated independent research projects under the supervision of the PI and co-PI. The undergraduates and co-PI incorporated the results of these projects into an annual outreach event for the general public at Mountain Lake.
